posts.cooked:
In the file: swerve-lib/Mk4ModuleConfiguration.java at prod · democat3457/swerve-lib · GitHub

There is a drive current limit set to 80 amps. However on the NEO website, it says that the maximum continuous current limit is 60 amps. Why is the drive current limit set to 80 if the max is 60 and if so shouldn’t this be changed to protect NEOs from burning out?

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked: How long is continuous? How long will you run it at 80 amps?

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: 80 Amps sounds way too high.  I’m 90% sure that will spin your tires…  You want to actually CHECK the slip threshold.
Part of my role is to manage the budget.  NEO’s are limited to 40A and 550s to 15A.

posts.name: Reza
posts.cooked: But they can momentarily spike up higher.

posts.name: Orion DeYoe
posts.cooked:
Drivetrains are typically traction limited before they reach maximum current.  The current limit should be determined experimentally.  This is often done by putting the robot against a wall on field-accurate carpet and pushing against the wall at full power with a low current limit.  The current limit is slowly increased until the wheels slip and then the current limit is backed down slightly.  The final number depends highly on robot mass as well as traction material so each team needs to do this calibration individually.

Running a NEO at 80A is fine as long as you don’t do it continuously.  Take a look at the locked rotor testing page ( NEO Brushless Motor - Locked-rotor Testing ) for more detailed information.  For mechanisms like launchers or arms it’s typically okay to have an 80A current limit because the mechanism only operates in short bursts of power.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: You can also just do a slow voltage ramp and record the current the entire time, similar to the quasistatic test run by SysId.  This means you can just do a single test iteration without modifying any motor controller settings.
